page.title: 14SOME HISTORY OF WOORE
page.content: One explanation of the name of the village is that it came from the Anglo-Saxon word{"Oure"}meaning a boundary. The village is in the{Domesday Book, where it is shown as held by Wiiliam Pantolf. In medieval times the most notable family of Woore was the{de Bulkeleys. The village was on the{stage-coach route to Holyhead, and the Swan hotel had stables where the church is now. The village{workhouse}was at Irelands Cross, and it is now a house. When the{railway}was opened from Stoke to Market Drayton, people used to have a ride out to Pipe Gate and Woore for a day out of the smoke. There is an{ash tree,}which stands at the highest point, and tradition says that it may be seen for many miles, and that it has always been replaced.
